reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only put a few hours into this game, but can already tell there's a mountain of possibilities here. Definitely BUY this, support the developers and follow it closely!

If you like classic RTS games like Settlers, Majesty or the Anno series, this is a very well-produced hybrid of those in progress. You build a city, manage resource production / distribution, train a military and fight off monsters / other cities. There's also a roguelike, sandbox element in that your city exists on an overworld map with other cities who will trade with you, invade you, or be subject to invasions/raids.

Though it's not complete yet, it's clear that the developers have done a good, solid job of building the engine and foundations -- that is to say, from here it seems like a lot of the groundwork has been done and the rest will simply be adding content and features.

Features I would like to see implemented in the future:

- Greater varience of buildings/skins, or random rotations (at present there is only one look" for houses
recommended: which can make blocks of houses which you need lots of
hoursPlayed: look somewhat bland or boring)\n\n- More supply/demand dynamic for trading. Resources often have a relatively set cost that hardly deviates at all. I would like to see something implemented where resources will fluctuate more heavily in price
voteText: even between other cities. It makes trading more exciting/dynamic
helpfulPercent: as currently if two other cities want to buy your resource
votesHelpful: they will both largely offer an identical price. I would like to see this fluctuate
votesTotal: so that a player would have to pay attention to trading -- and could even mean that a player running a "trading village" could be economically viable
votesFunny: as buying resources low from certain cities and selling high to others at a profit could potentially work.\n\n- More permanent overworld map changes as the game progresses. i.e. other cities going to war and "taking over" rivals
commentsCount: which would in essence form small "kingdoms" (say
column16: a certain NPC city will then own 2 or 3 cities). Also perhaps something like "invasions" of other cities from monsters
column17: so that cities would become "monster citadels" or "lairs" if they are taken over.\n\n- More military options (siege weapons
column18: different units (perhaps using shields and swords as resources as well))\n\n- Better "fortification" options. Right now there are stone walls and stone gatehouses
column19: but only wooden stockades and no wooden gatehouses. This would be a valuable addition.\n\n- More monsters
column20: though I think the devs have already mentioned wanting to do this. Goblins
column25: one of my most favourite in recent memory
column26: and I can't wait until the content starts being more fully fleshed out. There's so much potential here."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI can't say this is a game for everyone.  It has a learning curve, and the game is unforgiving.  It is a fun city building game with elements of pre-built in conflict.  Neighbors WILL invade.  you have local unfriendlies that will compete for city space and block access to resources.  but the worst enemy is you.  i had to restart multiple times to get the right" build for my city.  some of the problems with design only become apparent later on in the game.  for example
date: i built my city in such a way that my peddlers (a food resource distribution node) would not cover the area needed
recommended: and i was out of resources to create a new node
hoursPlayed: but i need more houses to house more workers to.... you get the idea.\n\nThere are things in the game that are not intuitive (mostly UI issues) that are annoying
voteText: more than game breaking.  so be prepared for some tedium.  Overall

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Genre: city builder Settlers-style
review: version 0.7.3

-------important note----------
Hearthlands is not too difficult! Those complaints come from people who play on normal" setting and can't deal with it. Hint: You can set it to "very easy" and adjust every other aspect in the settings!
------------------------------------------------

Hearthlands must have come a long way in the past couple of months because I can't see any of the mentioned negative points. This game is pretty fantastic by now. People complain about the difficulty. Well
date: that's more of a misunderstanding. Your neighbours will bully you and eventually invade you if you don't build up defences. That's how it should be btw.\nSo don't just build a farming community and expect to be left in peace. Build some troops.\nIf you don't feel like fighting
recommended: then you can comfortably set the a.i. to passive mode. You can also improve relations by trade and other means.\nYou can also select a sandbox mode. You can set up the game any way you like. Difficulty
voteText:
kind of dwellings...
You can select 1 of 4 cultures to play as. The options are huge.

Hearthlands even feels polished by now. You finally have a zoom function which I imagine must have sucked without. The game runs absolutely stable. There's so much to do and it's just so much fun. Can't believe this has been under the radar for such a long time.
The devs are providing frequent updates

Either way, the game itself has a lot to offer I've only played it for a few hours and still I'm far from reaching the end game". This game is totally worth 15€ but it gets very frustrating when failing at the easiest difficulty and with not a lot of rivals on. Either I just suck at this game or it's just very hard

votesTotal: this is a great game and company to support.  Very few games make me smile
votesFunny: give me glimmers of happiness... this game does just that by evoking my childhood imagination for sim cities once again.  "Hearthlands" is the perfect compliment to my other work -art- as it inspires & amuses.  Just how many little villages didn't make it?  How many millions slaughtered just so that we could survive on?  This is a great break from the intensity of "Crusader Kings" yet still one can entertain the same novel characters & events in their own storybook style sandbox.   --  Oldschool Respect -- Critics of the graphics should understand the homage to the early era of sims & keep in mind the appeal to a generation which utilized their imaginations more than their eyes.  Tolkien's favorite rendering of his books was of the Hobbit and Golem doing riddles in the dark

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor major part it's just a copy of Zeus: Master of Olympus. Most things work exactly the same way but there are several different industries, different buildings to built and material chains to construct. Though if you like Zeus then you are sure to like this one too. Definitely enjoyed building new types of industry and gathering resources. Tutorial could use more expanding though, needs explanation about how trading and military work. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys more town building focused rather than military focused town building games, as you can choose to pretty much turn off any kind of fighting, and to anyone who likes Zeus, Pharaoh and Emperor: Rise of the middle kingdom type of games.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI played this game on Linux in Early Access and is without bugs. I had a resolution problem that made it unplayable, but the dev was quick to help me fix it. It is cute, played for a few hours (10 or 20 don't know why steam shows 2 hrs) as the nords. I liked the fact that nords can't grow crops. The resource management is great and factions are well ballanced. Somehow I got the impression tht you can actually conquer the map townby town, when I realized that I am wrong I lost the interest in playing. The game has nothing that tops Caesar 3 for example, but for the nostalgics it is worth dropping a penny for. I'd reccommend you to hold your breath until it comes out of early access, nothing to do with the current game just a general advice.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPretty fun city builder, with deep supply chains, trading, monster raids, army building. Looks easy enough in screenshots but has a nice depth and lots of freedom in how you build your town. You can make it as easy or as hard as you like, and there are different factions you can play as which focus on certain troop and building types. Maps are vast and the beautification factor is a nice mechanic to make the OCD builders and min/maxers happy while trying to get the most out of their layouts. Surprised at the quality so far, in my two hours with it I already see myself playing a hell of a lot more of this than I ever did Banished. Old school meet the new.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was a lot of fun.

http://youtu.be/HE7noZR94Aw
Some bugs are present and work is needed (e.g. invaders trapped on islands at the edge of the map). I also didn’t like how combatants walk in a line and engage in battle one by one. 6 directional movement and roads would be good, so this game isn’t full of 90* zig-zags. An ability to zoom in and out would be nice too. As with many good single-player games some form of multiplayer would be awesome, but it’s not practical in this case anyway.
-----Lots of choice for different situations (e.g. severals choices for alcoholic needs, and you can use diplomacy or a strong defence).
It was a welcome challenge to finetune my city. But more information needed about industry requirements e.g. how much livestock and crops are needed to support farms and how many farms and resource gathering structures are needed to support production of food other goods) would be mice.
-----If you don’t know this you either build too much or too little of certain things and you can’t plan your city properly
You end up with a weak links in process i.e. inadequate supplies of a single material needed to produce items for you city
I had to figure out ratios by trial and error.

However in the end it was very satisfying to build a relatively large city and tame it. With 20+ hours invested into this game I’ve definitely got my money’s worth

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a very well-executed take on the city-building genre.  At its core, it plays similar to SimCity, but it takes the concept in new directions.

It's easy to get into, and there's a lot of depth.  The tutorial is straightforward and quick, which is nice; it doesn't hit you with unwanted dialogue like many tutorials do.

The gameplay is set up in a way such that new concepts are introduced at just the right pace: after you've produced enough food for your townspeople, they start asking for other luxuries like alcohol, furniture, and boots.  Amusingly, they put alcohol at a higher priority than everything except food.  Once you have a production line set up for the resources they want, their houses automatically get upgraded, and you continue onto their next wishes.  The pacing is great.

As time goes on, AI-controlled opponents will start to interact with you.  This gives you some options for trading, so you can get rid of excess resources in exchange for the resources you want.  They also apparently attack you, and you can build weapons for defense, but I haven't experienced that yet since I've only played for an hour so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR: Buy Gnomaria. It's cheaper, way more features, and succeeds everywhere this game fails.

I would like to put a huge disclaimer here before writing a scathing review. Some points..
1. The game is in alpha, there still can be a huge amount of improvements made and the game will only get better.
2. I don't really hate the game it's not really that bad. See my review for Skyshines Bedlam, now that is a crappy game! But given the option to put a only a thumbs up or a thumbs down, I have to choose thumbs down at this time. but it's barely a thumbs down, mind you. I'm simply comparing it to other games (like Gnomaria) and it just falls short is all.
3. The dev is very active, working his ♥♥♥ off, and I do have hopes for this game. Plus I love supporting small companies, so don't regret buying it.
4. I bought this game simple for the fact it had a 90% positive rating. That's why when playing it and finding some glaring issues, I was a bit surprised.
5. $10 is pretty good value. Once it get's more polished I can see this being quite favorable. So I can't hold that against it. In fact quite the contrary. I wish more games in this price range existed.
Ok now for stuff I don't like this game.

-Music. It's simply horrid. you turn if off immediately. There is this chicken noise also that chimes every 5 seconds, making you pull your hair out, especially if you're wearing headphones.  2/10

- Combat. First, there is a goblin that takes a beeline path from his base to yours. The same exact path every time. At first you have to chase him with the couple troops you can muster, but then you just end up placing a tower in his path to destroy him. Next, a sewer opens up in some random spot near your town, and 3 jelly monsters pop out of it. You just park your troops on top of this to stop them. But since everything is on 5 minute timers, you just leave some troops on top of this forever and let them level up. Then unless you pay out the nose to the other factions demanding constant crap from you, they will eventually attack. This isn't much of an issue though, because they just show up on the edge of the map and stand there until you can get around to killing them. Or you can just leave them out there and completely ignore.

After you raise an army, you think Hey I should go attack my enemies". So you pull up the combat screen
date: say which enemy you want to atatck
recommended: how many troops you want to send
hoursPlayed: and then receive a message you lost. You don't actually get to see the battle or know how you lost

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love city building games.  This game reminds me of the elements of Anno series and banished.  I think this game is a unique gem of city building games.

I enjoyed getting a massive city and armies and crushing all that opposed me.  If you are not into this route you can play on easy and free city build to create good looking cities with difficult supply chains.

Focus on creating supply lines equal to what they consume.  Use all the available menus to check consumption and supply to build good sized cities.

I was also suprised the game was updated as well very soon after I bought it.  I'll probably check in a few months after it's updated again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fans of Pharoah, Caesar, and Emperor will instantly be familiar with the gameplay and general gist of Hearthlands.  And I think that's a good thing.  The first three games I mentioned are all still very playable, and just as engaging as they were years ago... and Hearthlands is carrying on that tradition.  The graphics are charming if a bit cartoonish... as soon as I saw the red/white mushrooms I thought of Smurfs and a flash of horror crossed my brain... but that's fine.  The tutorial is quite helpful, and does a good job of easing you into the increasingly complex world of city-building and chains of production.

I can already feel myself reaching for some graph paper to plot out optimum city planning, which is something I did with Caesar... which in itself is a pretty big compliment.  I'm interested to see what else gets added in to the game down the road.  This game has the potential to be another great time sink.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVery unforgiving, super adorable, and way more complex than it lets on. Awesome game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game with A TON of potential
I like replay value and this has it.  The game offers diveristy and a great challenge! Over and over you will improve your kingdom, its layout, distribution, and learn to properly proportion supply and population.

The game is at first difficult but allows you to manipulate different criteria such as starting cash and potential threats.  Dont feel bad starting at 20-30% difficulty;  Im just getting to 60-70% myself!

I look forward to what will come, I highly reccomend this to anyone into RTS and/or city builders
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A rather detailled city builder that combines the better parts of the Caesar and the Settler series. Removes maintenance walker for the better and makes combat more transparent. For an EA game it already offers a solid endless game mode, lovely graphics and gameplay variety.

Pro: Many multi-step production chains, spells and varied primary sector.

Con: Generic, rather gnomish setting (matter of taste).

Alternative: Lethis - Path of Progress, has a more fanciful setting and a long campaign, but less varied trading and production chains, no military.

Early Access Review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

5/10

- The game still is lacking a lot in order for it to feel like a fulfilling game, since winning is very limited and involves monotanous fighting and training (takes too long).
- The difficulties levels are really off. This is what turned me away initially. Normal will have your city destroyed an hour in, when the AI has 30 troops and you have 4, or if any at all. Switching to easy made this child's play, which got boring pretty fast. Hopefully they can change the normal mode to meet between the current easy and normal.
- It's obviously early access, so there are some things missing (like you get magic points but can't do anything with them)
voteText: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well... 2.5 out of 5 stars so far.
I understand this is beta, but it's really difficult to get thru more than a few years worth of growth without something catastrophic happening and destroying your progress. Given how slowly things develop, this is extremely frustrating! I want to be able to actually play some of the game without having to divert to 'god mode'. If folks are just supposed to mess around with this for 20 minutes, it needs to be waaaaaay cheaper than $15.
What I don't like: as soon as you hit go, the calendar is ticking, but it can take months for immigrants to make their way across the map to your city. I think time should start when they step on a road, or get within X number of spaces.
Only male leaders??? Rly?
What I do like: you have to think about what you grow or build when, and sync up all your systems so they flow one into another. Digging the 16 bit look.
What I want: more options for changing details of civilizations, FEMALE LEADERS (fer xrists sake...)
Pro tip: start your city as high north as you can, as all your immigrants will come from the northern edge of the map.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My storage yards are full of eggs.

It's a complete game. There are many things that seem to need some tweaking.

There's endless potential for diplomacy, alliances, espionage to unlock buildings unavailible to the current nationality! Also multiplayer with co-operative play on the same town or two separate towns or versus with an AI ally!

I'm hopeful, but understand if the things above don't get implemented in the main game. It would be well worth the money if an expansion would come out with such features.

Good game, all in all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For some reason, I had no Internet when I was playing this game, so Steam didn't record it, but anyway, I'll do my first review of a game ever.

I recommend this game to anyone who likes City Building games and Strategy. Well, at least, I will recommend it in the future.
Here's a few problems:
- Since this is still an unfinished game, there isn't any good tutorial
- The game's civilizations are not balanced. I have found that playing with Eastern is by far the easiest way to play.
- Some limitations of the game are a bit annoying. For example, everybody should be able to fish. There is no geographical exceptions to fishing usually. Everybody used to fish because it was available as a source of food.
- The game is EXTREMELY HARD or COMPLETELY EASY. The difficulty meter is broken I'm telling you. Unless nothing costs a thing, it can get really hard. Everybody starts being mad with you all at the same time, even if you trade a lot.
- I often feel like the guys that deliver the stuff just deliver food or something. Everybody needs beer or something and since there's only 0.1 of food left, he decides to deliver food instead, which ends up causing the houses to devolve.
- I have seen a few bugs in the flag colour selections. I try to switch colours, but then it switches the logo, and when I want to select white and I'm at black, I need to pass by yellow, which switches the other colour, so I have to go all the way back to black, select the other colour, etc.
- Getting a steady income is actually really hard. When you start making soldiers, making enough money to pay for them all is really hard. Apart from taxes and trade, there's no income, if you're an Easterner.
- Sometimes, I get overloaded with a bunch of resources. In my last gameplay, I had over 500 wurst. I was selling all the meat I could, but I had to make wurst to make my people eat it, but then there was too much food and all. The problem here is that, we can't throw away resources or sell them at a reduced price to nobody".
- Other countries start with soldiers and get a lot of them really fast
date: whilst it takes ages for us and we have none in the beginning.\n\nThe list goes on and on

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've played games like COC on your mobile or another strategy based builder of the same sort you'll be able to relate to Hearthlands easily. It's simple in the way that up until around the 7th year all you really have to worry about is keeping your villagers fed and plague-less and you'll be fine. Around the 8th year prepare for a ♥♥♥♥ storm because woops your sewers just broke and there are monsters climbing around your city that look surprisingly similar to hounds from Dont Starve but instead bounce like fuzzy balls and, most probably, smell like ♥♥♥♥. You will be attacked by wizards, trolls, other kingdoms and then when you think you've gone through it all; the elements will rise against you and you'll wonder why on earth you ever purchased such a game that is so pretty and basic-looking but pretty much ♥♥♥♥s you from every angle.

10/10 well done on this game, seriously.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only played a little bit, but I can see where this is going. It's a lot less like a city builder, and a lot more like Towns or Gnomoria.

I think it's a very enjoyable game, and I'd be more likely to play for hours on end, if only I didn't have to get up in a few hours.

No worries, there's always tomorrow.

The progression is fun, the tutorial is useful, and it's certainly the kind of game where you can do a few things, then watch it for a bit while it progresses (my favourite kind of game, to be honest.

Worth the asking price, without a doubt.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS IS A REVIEW OF THE EARLY ACCESS PORTION OF THE GAME!

The Concept of the game is great, it's pretty much like all city builders. I feel though the layout and map generation is lazy. There's a lack of features and I don't feel like everything is properly categorized. You have over 20 different tabs, and the map itself is normally filled half-way up with houses! The progression of the city is way to quick, and since you can't rotate the buildings yet, you normally want to start on the left side so everything can look right! It feels like it's closer to farmville but speed-up. In the end this game is not worth $15!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Time for another update!

I'm still playing the hell out of this game and the devs are still updating content and tweeking, including adding more buildings to the game and messing with the AI.

One major change I'm not so sure I enjoy is that invasions are now handled off screen and via popup notice.  Before this update invasions where a real challenge and to survive on easy setting you still had to prepare defense structures and have at least 3 armies pretty early in the game.  This beat me down a ton but I learned as I lost and adjusted accordingly.  Now the invasions seem totally pointless as I never lose them and suffer no consequences for the battle, a battle it should be noted again that I never get to see.

Also of note is that getting a notification every time a new trade route opens or a current one ends does not serve me much in terms of usage.  At least compared to how frequently they occur.  I check trade routes regularly as is and don't need to be remind.  However, it would be really nice to be able to jump to the spot on the map where my citizens are being killed!  Nearly every game I have played has put me in the spot of scowering the map over and over trying to find where a citizen or merchant has been killed.  It can be something as silly as a sewer monster hiding behind a build (and hard to see even with the transparent building setting on) and completely ruining my towns reputation.

Population growth is still off balance imho.  It seems that my town rep never becomes positive no matter what I do.  Have a walled in, protected town with a booming economy and no enemies on the map?  Still terrible rating.  It either is a flaw in the game or I'm too dumb to figure out something right in front of me.

As usualy my complaints sound ungrateful considering how much I absolutley adore this game.  It truly is a hidden gem of the citing building genre and I can't stop playing it for too long.  I hope the end game content sharpens up as the devs continue to tweek.


TRIPLE UPDATE:  Not even at V1.0 and this is one of my favorite games of all time.  80 hours in and I finally have a grip on the very easy setting game.  It's kinda awesome figuring a game out with nary a wiki available, at least not in English.  I can't wait to see what the devs add next (will Magic be useful?  Zoom function?  Better pathfinding for military units?).  This is the city building/resource management game I've been waiting for since forever.  Thanks!


DOUBLE UPDATE:  I love this game.  Don't buy it.  You'll never want to stop playing.


UPDATE:  I think I love this game, I'm sure I'm terrible at it and I know I'll lose many many more hours into it.  HOW DO I EVEN SUSTAIN?



I've put in almost 5 hours since I bought this game the other night, so I really really like it.  However, I'm having a terrible time keeping everything straight.  This is probably my own shortcomings, but when I go to make military units I'm never sure if I have enough leather and feather (ha!) going to my industry buildings instead of food.  I would love, LOVE a zoom in/out attached to the mouse wheel.  Being able to get a bird's eye view of the developing city would help a ton as it gets bigger and bigger.

As is, the placement mechanizm is great, the art work charming and it's basically a deeper, less combat and mission reliant verison of Majesty.  Which is pretty damn awesome.

TL;DR
You need military units or everyone dies.
10/10 will fail more over and over.
